trial_identification.studytitle: Melbourne Infant Study - Bacille Calmette Guérin (BCG) for Allergy & Infection Reduction
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Randomised, Controlled Trial to Determine if BCG Immunisation at Birth Reduces Allergy and Infection in Infants

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of infection and infectious agents

interventions.interventions:
Other interventions - BCG
No Intervention: No BCG - No BCG
Experimental: BCG - Mycobacterium bovis BCG (Bacille Calmette Guérin) vaccine, Danish Strain 1331
Other interventions: BCG

primaryOutcome.outcome: Prevalence of positive skin prick tests - Allergic disease measured by prevalence of positive skin prick tests (SPT)

Prevalence of eczema - Allergic disease measured by the prevalence of eczema determined by parental report, eczema medication use, medical consultation and an assessment by the research team at 12 months
Prevalence of lower respiratory tract infections - Allergic disease measured by the prevalence of lower respiratory tract infections in the first 12 months of life

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Prevalence and severity of challenge-proven food allergy in study participants with a positive SPT
Prevalence of hospital admissions for respiratory illness
Other measures of infection including febrile episodes
Laboratory measures of the immune response

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
1. To determine if BCG immunisation at birth, compared to no BCG immunisation, leads to a reduction in measures of allergy and infection in the first 12 months of life.
2. To evaluate the immunological mechanisms underlying the non-specific effects of BCG by comparing markers of immunity between the BCG and non-BCG groups.
